definitions.definition: to die because you have been underwater too long and you cannot breathe; to kill somebody by holding them underwater

examples.text: Two children drowned after falling into the river.
He had attempted to rescue the drowning man.
They had drowned the unwanted kittens.
The ship's captain refused to leave them to drown.
They were commended for saving a four-year-old from drowning.

definitions.definition: to make something very wet; to completely cover something in water or another liquid

examples.text: The fruit was drowned in cream.

definitions.definition: to be louder than other sounds so that you cannot hear them

examples.text: She turned up the radio to drown out the noise from next door.
His words were drowned out by jeers and whistling.

definitions.definition: to have so much of something that you cannot deal with it

examples.text: We're drowning in applications so please don't write in.

definitions.definition: to get drunk in order to forget your problems

wordOrigin: Middle English (originally northern): related to Old Norse drukkna ‘to be drowned’, also to drink.
